Title.evidence: Impact of Patient Characteristics on Insulin Response During Non-Cardiac Surgery: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised using a computer-generated sequence

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included adult patients scheduled for non-cardiac surgery

Intervention.evidence: The intervention involved intraoperative intravenous insulin administration, with no comparator group

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to assess these effects in non-cardiac surgical patients

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the change in blood glucose concentration 30 minutes after an initial insulin bolus

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Participants were randomised using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealed via sealed envelopes

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 202 patients were randomised, with 101 in each group

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was performed on all participants using an intention-to-treat approach

Result_Outcome.evidence: Blood glucose concentrations decreased by 8.3 ±10 mg dl-1 (0.46 ± 0.56 mmol litre-1) per unit of insulin. The response was similar in patients with and without diabetes [adjusted mean difference (97.5% CI): 0.2 (-3.9, 4.2) mg dl-1, 0.01 (-0.22, 0.24) mmol litre-1, P = 0.93]
